Library for helping print things prettily, in Clojure

2023/07/23
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.

The article showcases a library called "clj-commons/pretty" that aims to provide developers with a tool for printing things in a visually appealing manner in Clojure. This library offers various features that can be useful for developers working with console output, stack traces, or binary data.

One of the key features of clj-commons/pretty is its ability to print out sequences of bytes with color-coding inspired by hexyl. This can be particularly helpful when analyzing and comparing binary data. Additionally, the library can also generate a delta of two byte sequences, highlighting the differences using background colors.

It is worth noting that clj-commons/pretty is compatible with Clojure 1.10 and above. However, parts of the library, such as the clj-commons.ansi namespace, can also be used with Babashka. It is important to mention that while clj-commons/pretty works well with JVM exceptions, its approach to exceptions is incompatible with Babashka's interpreter.

Overall, clj-commons/pretty provides developers with a convenient tool for enhancing the readability and aesthetics of their console output, stack traces, and binary data. It is a valuable addition to any Clojure developer's toolkit.
